intro: Anthochlamys polygaloides, commonly known as the narrowleaf milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender, often hairy stems and small, clustered leaves. The plant produces yellow to orange flowers that bloom in late spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its seed pods are typically slender and contain several small, kidney-shaped seeds. Anthochlamys polygaloides is adapted to arid environments and is often found in rocky soils and open habitats.
